values.description:
How to install and run valgrind and perftools: [perftools](http://gazebosim.org/wiki/Troubleshooting#Profiling)

** Valgrind **

Try running valgrind to make sure it's installed properly

  `valgrind --tool=callgrind gzserver`

  'kcachegrind callgrind.out`

Then run atlas

  `roslaunch atlas_utils atlas.launch gzname:=gzserver_callgrind`

  `kcachegrind ~/.gazebo/callgrind.out`

** Perftools **

First try running perftools on the command line to make sure you have installed it properly:

  `perf record gzserver worlds/pr2.world`

  `perf report`

Then try running atlas

  `roslaunch atlas_utils atlas.launch gzname:=gzserver_perf`

  `perf report -i ~/.gazebo/perf.data`
values.title: Added perf tool run script

summary.raw:

** Perftools **

First try running perftools on the command line to make sure you have installed it properly:

  `perf report`

Then try running atlas

Perftools

First try running perftools on the command line to make sure you have installed it properly:

perf report

Then try running atlas

perf report -i ~/.gazebo/perf.data

values.description:
When running `vrc_task_1.launch` with `VRC_CHEATS_ENABLED=1`:

    cd drcsim/tutorials
    export ROS_PACKAGE_PATH=`pwd`:$ROS_PACKAGE_PATH
    rosrun atlas_teleop nanokontrol.py 3 # Replace 3 with the right ID for your mixer
    rosrun atlas_teleop drc_vehicle_teleop.py

Buttons:

* 0: enter car
* 1: exit car

Axes:

* 0: hand brake
* 1: brake pedal
* 2: direction (R/F only, no N)
* 3: gas pedal
* 4: hand wheel

Basically, use axes 0-2 to get things set up, then drive with axes 3 and 4.
values.title: add slider teleop for drc_vehicle using cheats

summary.raw:
When running `vrc_task_1.launch` with `VRC_CHEATS_ENABLED=1`:

    cd drcsim/tutorials
    export ROS_PACKAGE_PATH=`pwd`:$ROS_PACKAGE_PATH
    rosrun atlas_teleop nanokontrol.py 3 # Replace 3 with the right ID for your mixer
    rosrun atlas_teleop drc_vehicle_teleop.py

Buttons:

* 0: enter car
* 1: exit car

Axes:

* 0: hand brake
* 1: brake pedal
* 2: direction (R/F only, no N)
* 3: gas pedal
* 4: hand wheel

Basically, use axes 0-2 to get things set up, then drive with axes 3 and 4.
summary.html:
When running vrc_task_1.launch with VRC_CHEATS_ENABLED=1:

cd drcsim/tutorials
export ROS_PACKAGE_PATH=`pwd`:$ROS_PACKAGE_PATH
rosrun atlas_teleop nanokontrol.py 3 # Replace 3 with the right ID for your mixer
rosrun atlas_teleop drc_vehicle_teleop.py

Buttons:

  • 0: enter car
  • 1: exit car

Axes:

  • 0: hand brake
  • 1: brake pedal
  • 2: direction (R/F only, no N)
  • 3: gas pedal
  • 4: hand wheel

Basically, use axes 0-2 to get things set up, then drive with axes 3 and 4.

values.description:
This needs the following pull-request to be effective:

https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/533/make-gazebo-produce-less-console-output/diff

I also ran:

`find . -name '*.world' -exec gzsdf convert {} \;`

`find . -name '*.launch' -exec sed -i -e 's/output="screen"/output="log"/g' {} \;`

values.description:
I have seen vrc scoring task2 failing from time to time and want to be sure that the robot is not lying on the floor at the end of scoring tests.

This implements checks to run before anything. I would like to get rid of code duplication, feel free to propose the best way to do so? install a __init__.py in test directory? Any other method?

I have seen vrc scoring task2 failing from time to time and want to be sure that the robot is not lying on the floor at the end of scoring tests.

This implements checks to run before anything. I would like to get rid of code duplication, feel free to propose the best way to do so? install a __init__.py in test directory? Any other method?
summary.html:
I have seen vrc scoring task2 failing from time to time and want to be sure that the robot is not lying on the floor at the end of scoring tests.

This implements checks to run before anything. I would like to get rid of code duplication, feel free to propose the best way to do so? install a init.py in test directory? Any other method?

values.description:
Modify ContactModelPlugin (used by SandiaHandPlugin's tactile sensors) to use custom contact publishers. 

Requires Gazebo pull request #[543](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/543/contact-manager-custom-publisher/diff) to compile as it needs ContactManager.hh.

Together with Gazebo pull request #[543](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/543/contact-manager-custom-publisher/diff), RTF increased from 
0.69~0.7 to 0.77~0.78.
values.title: Made use of custom contact publisher in plugin

Modify ContactModelPlugin (used by SandiaHandPlugin's tactile sensors) to use custom contact publishers. 

Requires Gazebo pull request #[543](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/543/contact-manager-custom-publisher/diff) to compile as it needs ContactManager.hh.

Together with Gazebo pull request #[543](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/543/contact-manager-custom-publisher/diff), RTF increased from 
0.69~0.7 to 0.77~0.78.
summary.html:
Modify ContactModelPlugin (used by SandiaHandPlugin's tactile sensors) to use custom contact publishers.

Requires Gazebo pull request #543 to compile as it needs ContactManager.hh.

Together with Gazebo pull request #543, RTF increased from 0.69~0.7 to 0.77~0.78.

values.description:
- Replaced calls to `ros::Publisher's` `getNumSubscribers()` by a local counter. I see an increase in 0.02~0.03 in RTF by doing so. I am not entirely sure why. While the function call takes around tens of microsec, it seems to lock a mutex that has side effects on performance.

- Keep track of tactile publisher's subscriber count in SandiaHandPlugin. Around another 0.04 increase in RTF if there are no subscribers to the tactile sensor while atlas's hands are in contact with other collisions.
values.title: Avoid publishing when no subscribers

summary.raw:
- Replaced calls to `ros::Publisher's` `getNumSubscribers()` by a local counter. I see an increase in 0.02~0.03 in RTF by doing so. I am not entirely sure why. While the function call takes around tens of microsec, it seems to lock a mutex that has side effects on performance.

- Keep track of tactile publisher's subscriber count in SandiaHandPlugin. Around another 0.04 increase in RTF if there are no subscribers to the tactile sensor while atlas's hands are in contact with other collisions.
summary.html:
• Replaced calls to ros::Publisher's getNumSubscribers() by a local counter. I see an increase in 0.02~0.03 in RTF by doing so. I am not entirely sure why. While the function call takes around tens of microsec, it seems to lock a mutex that has side effects on performance.

  • Keep track of tactile publisher's subscriber count in SandiaHandPlugin. Around another 0.04 increase in RTF if there are no subscribers to the tactile sensor while atlas's hands are in contact with other collisions.

values.description:
Without this fix, the following sequence can happen:

 1. Subscribe via ROS to left camera.
 1. Subscribe via ROS to right camera.
 1. Kill the left subscriber.
 1. The right subscriber stops receiving images.

Left/right doesn't matter; the key is that you start two subscribers, one for each camera, then kill the first subscriber.

The fix is kind of ugly, in that I'm just making some of the state variables in `GazeboRosCameraUtils` into shared pointers and setting them to point to the same locations from within `GazeboRosMultiCamera`.  It would be better to push this bookkeping logic into the underlying Gazebo sensor.  But this should work for now, and there's a test (which fails without this fix).
values.title: fixes issue #217 (camera subscription problems)

summary.raw:
Without this fix, the following sequence can happen:

 1. Subscribe via ROS to left camera.
 1. Subscribe via ROS to right camera.
 1. Kill the left subscriber.
 1. The right subscriber stops receiving images.

Left/right doesn't matter; the key is that you start two subscribers, one for each camera, then kill the first subscriber.

The fix is kind of ugly, in that I'm just making some of the state variables in `GazeboRosCameraUtils` into shared pointers and setting them to point to the same locations from within `GazeboRosMultiCamera`.  It would be better to push this bookkeping logic into the underlying Gazebo sensor.  But this should work for now, and there's a test (which fails without this fix).
summary.html:
Without this fix, the following sequence can happen:

  1. Subscribe via ROS to left camera.
  2. Subscribe via ROS to right camera.
  3. Kill the left subscriber.
  4. The right subscriber stops receiving images.

Left/right doesn't matter; the key is that you start two subscribers, one for each camera, then kill the first subscriber.

The fix is kind of ugly, in that I'm just making some of the state variables in GazeboRosCameraUtils into shared pointers and setting them to point to the same locations from within GazeboRosMultiCamera. It would be better to push this bookkeping logic into the underlying Gazebo sensor. But this should work for now, and there's a test (which fails without this fix).

values.title: Added script for running valgrind memcheck

values.description:
Some code to allow tests to pass parameters which indicate, which gates to pass, what is the expected score after pass and if elapsed time should be enabled (1) or not (0).

For example:
```
      <param name="gates_to_pass"    value="0 1 2 2" />
      <param name="expected_score"   value="0 1 2 2" />
      <param name="expected_elapsed" value="1 1 1 1" />
```
Means that robot will be teleported to gate0, gate1, gate2 and gate2 again. Expected score should be 0, 1, 2 and 2. And elapsed time should be non zero after passing each gate.
values.title: Testing: cheating with scoring 'framework'

Some code to allow tests to pass parameters which indicate, which gates to pass, what is the expected score after pass and if elapsed time should be enabled (1) or not (0).

Means that robot will be teleported to gate0, gate1, gate2 and gate2 again. Expected score should be 0, 1, 2 and 2. And elapsed time should be non zero after passing each gate.

values.description: By shifting alignment position error check point on the coupling towards the spout, this should make insertion criteria easier.  I.e. we were originally checking alignment of the coupling link origin's x and y location to be within a small region relative to the spout link origin, but a better place to check is the center of the coupling collision cylinder surface towards the spout.
values.title: fix for issue #316.

summary.raw: By shifting alignment position error check point on the coupling towards the spout, this should make insertion criteria easier.  I.e. we were originally checking alignment of the coupling link origin's x and y location to be within a small region relative to the spout link origin, but a better place to check is the center of the coupling collision cylinder surface towards the spout.
summary.html: By shifting alignment position error check point on the coupling towards the spout, this should make insertion criteria easier. I.e. we were originally checking alignment of the coupling link origin's x and y location to be within a small region relative to the spout link origin, but a better place to check is the center of the coupling collision cylinder surface towards the spout.

values.description:
Some nan's were observed during automated testing using /atlas/set_pose (issue #313). Some inspection showed strange behavior right after the set_pose command was issued.

The fix is to pause and disable physics during /atlas/set_pose as is done in other VRCPlugin calls.

To stress test:
~~~
while rostopic pub -1 /atlas/set_pose geometry_msgs/Pose "{position: {z: 1.1}}"; do date; done
~~~

Or to move 22 times in a straight line:
~~~
for i in `seq 22`; do rostopic pub -1 /atlas/set_pose geometry_msgs/Pose "{position: {z: 1.1, x: $i.0}}"; done
~~~
values.title: Fix #313, race condition in /atlas/set_pose

summary.raw:
Some nan's were observed during automated testing using /atlas/set_pose (issue #313). Some inspection showed strange behavior right after the set_pose command was issued.

The fix is to pause and disable physics during /atlas/set_pose as is done in other VRCPlugin calls.

To stress test:
~~~
while rostopic pub -1 /atlas/set_pose geometry_msgs/Pose "{position: {z: 1.1}}"; do date; done
~~~

Or to move 22 times in a straight line:
~~~
for i in `seq 22`; do rostopic pub -1 /atlas/set_pose geometry_msgs/Pose "{position: {z: 1.1, x: $i.0}}"; done
~~~
summary.html:
Some nan's were observed during automated testing using /atlas/set_pose (issue #313). Some inspection showed strange behavior right after the set_pose command was issued.

The fix is to pause and disable physics during /atlas/set_pose as is done in other VRCPlugin calls.

To stress test:

while rostopic pub -1 /atlas/set_pose geometry_msgs/Pose "{position: {z: 1.1}}"; do date; done

Or to move 22 times in a straight line:

for i in `seq 22`; do rostopic pub -1 /atlas/set_pose geometry_msgs/Pose "{position: {z: 1.1, x: $i.0}}"; done
